title: Speed Radar Sign: Proportions from the Normal Distribution
question_text:
Police in a certain town recently set up a roadside speed radar with a sign that displays a vehicle's speed as it approaches the radar. This helps motorists be more aware of their speed, but it can also be used to track the speed of vehicles that pass the radar.
During the two weeks that the sign was in place, the mean speed of all vehicles passing the sign was found to be $42.8\text{ mph}$.
Assuming the distribution of speeds was approximately normal and the standard deviation of all vehicles that passed this sign was $5.3\text{ mph}$, what proportion of cars were traveling more than $40\text{ mph}$?
solution:
To solve this problem, we must first convert the raw data to a $z$-score. The formula for calculating $z$ is:

$$z = \dfrac { x - \mu }{ \sigma }$$

...where $x$ is the observed value or value of interest, $\mu$ is the mean, and $\sigma$ is the standard deviation.

$$z = \dfrac { 40 - 42.8 }{ 5.3 } = -0.53$$

We are looking for $p(z > -0.53)$. The easiest way to find this answer is to use your TI83/84 graphing calculator's normalcdf function. The normalcdf function finds probabilities associated with given $z$-scores. The syntax is: normalcdf (lower bound, upper bound, mean, standard deviation)
